Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing Cumulus Cloud Cover with Transilient Matrices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Model simulations of shallow cumulus clouds in the lower atmosphere demonstrate the sensitivity of predictions of future states to the representation of these clouds in the initial state of the atmosphere. Numerical schemes to handle these clouds in weather and climate models have been in existence for many years, yet new techniques continue to build upon and improve these schemes. This research will use a mathematical tool, called Transilient Matrices, to better characterize these clouds in the model's representation of the lower atmosphere and in turn improve forecasts of future weather and climate states based on these clouds. These improvements will in turn benefit society through an improved understanding of the sensitivity of weather and climate models to the characterization of shallow cumulus clouds in the lower atmosphere.

The proposed research seeks to test hypotheses for the amount of cloud cover associated with shallow cumulus. One such hypothesis relates the amount of cloud cover to the rate of cloud detrainment by a timescale that depends on cloud size and eddy diffusivity; this scale differs from the typical scale used in climate models by two orders of magnitude. The expression for timescale will be tested and refined using a well established mathematical tool known as the Transilient Matrix (TM) to output from large-eddy simulation (LES) and observations from cloud radar. Since differences in shallow cumulus cloud cover among various Global Climate Models (GCMs) have been identified as major contributions to uncertainty in climate projections, this research has the potential of improving forecasts of future climate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the physical processes that set the amount of convection and cloud cover in the atmosphere.  This has included a study of the interactions between radiation and cloud cover in the creation and intensification of tropical cyclones, an investigation of the processes that set the large cloud fraction in the tropical upper troposphere, and the mechanisms behind the apparent temperature invariance of tropical anvil clouds.  For example, the project has found that the profile of mean tropical cloudiness is influenced more by the sinks of clouds (e.g., from evaporative mixing and precipitation) than the sources (e.g., from convective detrainment).  This result contrasts with the standard argument for the top-heavy profile of cloud cover, which emphasizes sources of cloudiness induced by radiatively driven clear-sky circulations.  In subsequent work, the project looked at the hypothesis that anvil clouds remain fixed in temperature as the planet warms, at least to good approximation.  To test this claim, a cloud-resolving simulation was constructed that has only the minimal ingredients upon which rests the hypothesis for the anvils' temperature invariance. In those simulations, it is found that the proposed temperature invariance is violated: while the changes in the anvil temperatures are damped relative to changes in the sea-surface temperature, they are far from invariant. While anvil temperatures are not invariant, the tropopause temperature is invariant: the change in tropopause temperature is less than 4% of the change in SST.
